Chat1: ^Mrcalindas?Smiling "Remember to take a break once in a while, won’t you?"
^Mrcalindas?Smiling "You know you’re always welcome to join Paz and I for some tennis. It’s a nice way to get active and have some fresh air!"

s: ^I think I may be a bit clumsy for tennis. How about board games?
^I'll consider it. Meanwhile, can I talk to you about medical records?

Chat2: ^Mrcalindas?Smiling "I will never turn down a board game night-- any good at The Game of Life or Cranium? The grandkids love it."
^Mrcalindas?Smiling "I’d offer Uno, but it gets a little too competitive too fast."

s: ^It really does. Question, do you know how to help someone gather medical information?

Chat3: ^Mrcalindas?Smiling "Well in that case, ring me later, and we can find some time for a community board game night. Maybe the library wants to host something!"
^Mrcalindas?Smiling "Was there something you wanted to talk about?"

s: ^Yes, actually! A friend had some questions about family medical records.
^Sounds good!  Hey, how do you suggest people keep their medical history?"

Explain1: ^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Family health histories are a complete record of health information about someone and their relatives."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "It often includes information for a few generations and has information about both your immediate and extended family."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Since a family health history is a document of health, doctors are able to use it to see how patterns show up in families."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Some health conditions are strongly affected by genetics. Some things run in families, and knowing more about your history can help you make informed choices."

s: ^What are they used for beyond that?

Suggestion1: ^Mrcalindas_Day 4_Doctors offices can offer templates to help people get started in tracking their family medical history_Lila4-3

Suggestion1.#: notification Mrcalindas_Day 4_Doctors offices can offer templates to help people get started in tracking their family medical history_Lila4-3

Suggestion1: ^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Having a family health history can help doctors identify people at a greater risk for certain infections or diseases."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Some doctor’s offices have templates you can ask for to get started with the process and you can always reach out to them with questions if you have them."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Studying your family health history can provide a lot of insight and can be used to plan ahead."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Your history might suggest that you test for certain diseases or make lifestyle changes to reduce the risk of developing conditions that run in one’s family."

s: ^What sort of things do you write down in a family medical history?

Suggestion2: ^Mrcalindas_Day 4_When recording your family medical history, always document the diseases, allergies, ethnicity and death information for relatives if known_Lila4-4

Suggestion2.#: notification Mrcalindas_Day 4_When recording your family medical history, always document the diseases, allergies, ethnicity and death information for relatives if known_Lila4-4

Suggestion2: ^Mrcalindas?Neutral "When compiling your family medical history, you should always write down information starting with blood relatives to at least three generations if you know it."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Write down causes and ages of death, major medical conditions and age at diagnosis, and when any operations happened."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Also include ethnic background, as some conditions occur more frequently in some communities than in others."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "And it’s important to regularly update your information as time goes on."
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Other good questions to think about include: Are there allergies in the family and are they common? Is there a history of pregnancy losses?"
^Mrcalindas?Neutral "Also, try to capture any mental health information, and if certain health problems or symptoms seem prevalent."

s: ^Ah, that makes a lot of sense- you’re the best!
^This is so helpful. Thank you, Mr. Calindas!
^Thanks again, get ready to draw four!
